ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding of the financial markets and how things work at an institutional level. Some basic analytical tools to understand markets.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures are really interesting and Gorton's a cool guy. But class goes really quickly and it's easy to fall behind; homework doesn't have to be turned in and there are too few problems to help consolidate learning. Not much guidance provided on cases so it felt like we were just stumbling our way through things at times.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, a great primer on how "finance" works at a macro level.

Gorton is great, but he goes quickly so stay on top of things - especially since readings and homework are all optional so it's very easy to fall behind. Cases are pretty unstructured and you don't get much guidance on them so they can be rather frustrating. Exams are tough but everyone does poorly so it's probably fine. Probably take it Cr/D and just go for the lectures.
